name: .Net Core
description: A modern runtime for .Net that can run on windows/linux/docker.

name: Agile
description: Cvent has been an agile software development company for years. We have teams building software following scrum, kanban and a variety of methods depending on the need

name: apex.sh
description: We experimented with apex early on as way to manage our adoption of serverless on AWS. While it worked well for prototyping, it failed when it comes to security/compliance and flexibility. Instead, we've deferred to leveraging AWS CDK

name: API First Design
description: Cvent believes strongly in API First Design because it allows for iteration during the design phase. Getting the interface correct is the most important part of software development/design. We expect all APIs development to spend most of their time at this phase of development.

name: Apollo
description: Apollo is the core graphql framework that ships as part of CDF

name: appium
description: A test automation tool used for mobile tests

name: applitools
description: Applitools allows us to run e2e test automation and easily identify visual failures as they occur

name: asdf
description: A version manager for tools leveraged to build/deploy various projects.

name: AsyncAPI
description: AsyncAPI supports standardization and development tooling for event-driven and asynchronous APIs. Cvent have adopted the AsyncAPI specification alongside OpenAPI, to define our event-driven APIs for EventBridge and SQS.

name: Atlassian Changeset
description: Atlassian Changesets is a newer tool we're leveraging in our release process to handle semantic versioning and generate CHANGELOGs automatically

name: AWS Amplify
description: AWS amplify is a great tool for prototyping and getting started quickly. However, we've found that the magic winds up getting in the way once you need to start making updates to applications as they evolve over time. We prefer AWS CDK instead.

name: AWS API Gateway
description: Our primary API ingest point for all public facing APIs. This serverless platform allows us to throttle, cache apis and provide a unified interface to our customers. We also leverage it heavily for custom domains where our customers want a complete whitelabeled experience

name: AWS AppMesh
description: AWS AppMesh is a network routing service we're continuing to explore to see if it can provide the features we want such as (secure data in-transit, circuit breaker, retry, routing) and to see if it could help reduce the costs of deploying so many application load balancers. AWS has since launched ECS Service Connect and VPC Lattice which we believe will be better options going forward.

name: AWS AppSync
description: A managed graphql service that we tried out with our initial versions of CDF. However, we've discovered several areas of concerns centered around Lambda limits and developer experience so we've abandoned our use of AppSync and have since moved to Apollo

name: AWS Aurora Postgres
description: A managed relational database offering based on the Aurora storage engine but with Postgres compatibility. This allows us to easily scale out read slaves, auto-failover, 5x performance gains and more

name: AWS CDK
description: The CDK is our primary infrastructure as code platform. It provides an imperative model that lends itself to sharing reusable/sharable/testable components across Cvent for building infrastructure and serverless applications on AWS

name: AWS CloudFormation
description: AWS Cloudformation is a declarative infrastructure as code platform that we leverage to provision shared infrastructure code components. Most of our use cases for Cloudformation have moved over to AWS CDK but Cloudformation is really the underlying assembly language for infrastructure as code at AWS

name: AWS CloudFront
description: Cloudfront is the CDN we're using to cache assets and data at the edge.

name: AWS CloudMap
description: AWS CloudMap is a service discovery platform that is often used along with AppMesh to help with the dynamic nature of discovering how to communicate with a given service

name: AWS Codebuild
description: We've started moving away from Codebuild to our own managed EC2 instances because we're able to save on costs and have more flexibility with instance types.

name: AWS Codedeploy
description: AWS Codedeploy is a tool we ship as part of CDF to facilitate deployments with blue/green CI/CD.

name: AWS Codepipeline
description: AWS Codepipeline is a tool that we continue to experiment with and assess to see if we can provide a completely native aws CI/CD process with all the features we want

name: AWS Comprehend
description: The AWS Comprehend service has been experimented with for sentiment analysis and automatic catorization of data from user generated content like survey responses. There have been a few hackathon projects that have also experimented with this service but we haven't found the right use of this service in our products yet

name: AWS DynamoDB
description: We leverage DynamoDB as a serverless database option for certain use cases.

name: AWS ECR
description: AWS ECR is a managed service for hosting our docker images that are used to deploy to AWS ECS

name: AWS ECS/EC2
description: Our primary docker container orchestration platform. Using EC2 we're able to leverage spot instances, mixed clusters, specialized disk mounted volumes, gpus and more

name: AWS ECS/Fargate
description: We're in the phase of trying out Fargate as our primary docker container orchestration platform. This should allow us to reduce costs as well as easing the burden of maintaining several clusters across Cvent. CDF applications are deployed to Fargate.

name: AWS Elasticache
description: We leverage Elasticache/redis in our CDF applications and other places as a fast cache. This can be used to replace many use cases of Couchbase at Cvent.

name: AWS EMR
description: EMR is a service we're experimenting with as part of the data dev team

name: AWS EventBridge
description: Event Bridge is now a key part of our event driven architecture at Cvent.

name: AWS Kinesis Video Streams
description: KVS is a video streaming component of Kinesis that helps with streaming of video. We've began investigating how this service could be useful throughout our attendee hub product lines

name: AWS Kinesis
description: Kinesis is a streaming platform that we're experimenting with in order to stream data from point A to point B, C, D

name: AWS Lakeformation
description: Lakeformation is a service we're experimenting with as part of the data dev team

name: AWS Lambda
description: Use Lambda as a compute option to execute business logic when appropriate.

name: AWS Lattice
description: AWS VPC Lattice is what we're using for private connections/networking between AWS Accounts.

name: AWS MSK
description: Manged Kafka is what we're using to run kafka behind the ix-engine. This helps relieve some of the burden of maintaining this platform

name: AWS OpenSearch
description: A managed aws search service provides all of the functionality of elasticsearch plus additional security controls. This helps ease the burden of scaling up/down, patching, upgrading and maintaining this platform

name: AWS RDS MySQL
description: MySQL is another database we leverage only in circumstances that make sense, but in most cases we push for AWS Aurora

name: AWS RDS Postgres
description: A managed relational database offering for Postgres. We're putting this on hold as we've already began our migration to Aurora postgres

name: AWS Route53
description: Route53 is our primary DNS provider for most domains at Cvent

name: AWS S3
description: Static asset hosting (often in combination with Cloudfront) and storage of large documents and files. Less flexible querying capabilities and higher latency than Couchbase, but supports larger documents.

name: AWS SAM
description: AWS serverless application model (SAM) is another declarative approach to infrastructure as code, targetted at serverless to reduce boilerplate and improve on the developer experience. However, we've found it only works well in very isolated use cases and isn't flexible enough to work for longer term enterprise applications

name: AWS SQS
description: We leverage SQS as a serverless component of our event driven architecture.

name: Axe
description: Axe is a tool integrated to both Blucumber and WDIO. Axe is an accessibility testing engine for websites and other HTML-based user interfaces. It's fast, secure, lightweight, and was built to seamlessly integrate with any existing test environment so you can automate accessibility testing alongside your regular functional testing.

name: Bash
description: A scripting glue language used only as a last resort

name: Backstage
description: Backstage is an extensible developer-portal platform created by Spotify that improves governance, documentation and discovery of our software components.

name: bit.dev
description: We've began investigating bit.dev as a platform for managing all our UI dependencies as part of an end to end component ecosystem to make it easier to manage

name: Blucumber
description: Blucumber is an internal Cvent tool used for building/running selenium based test automation on our legacy applications. For newer applications we're favoring webdriver.io

name: Browser Stack
description: This is the selenium based browser testing platform we use to test/validate multiple browser versions against our products. We've begun moving towards Playwright instead.

name: C#
description: C# is the language used to develop significant parts of app.cvent.com (ie. Normandy, Legacy, Core).

name: Carina
description: The Cvent design system for building beautiful UIs

name: CDF
description: CDF (Cvent Development Framework) is a framework for designing, building, deploying infrastructure, web applications, mobile applications and services at Cvent.

name: cfn-lint
description: The cfn-lint tool allows us to enforce best practices and security rules around all our cloudformation infrastructure as code. This tool is mandated by our build/deploy pipelines (CDK or native cloudformation)

name: Checkmarx
description: Checkmarx is a tool we leverage to scan our source code during CI/CD for security vulnerabilities

name: Chef
description: Chef is the configuration managment tool we leverage to configure/install software throughout Cvent. Overtime we're slowly starting to replace Chef with pre-baked AMIs and immutable infrastructure

name: Clover
description: A java code coverage tool that we've stopped using because it operates on source code and didn't support java 11 when we moved away. We recommend jacoco instead

name: Cobertura
description: A java code coverage tool that we've depreacated in favor of jacoco because of it's support by the community, support for java 11, integrations with IDEs and more

name: Couchbase Mobile
description: Couchbasae mobile is the local database + sync technology we're using for project Falcon. It allows developers on device to read/write data as-if the database is always online and local while handling the syncing of data as network becomes available.

name: Couchbase
description: We prefer that teams now use modern cloud native database systems and serverless where possible

name: Creators
description: Creators is a tool that allows someone to get started quickly on a new project using the latest paved road technologies.

name: Dagger
description: Dagger (https://dagger.io/) is a devkit built on top of Docker's BuildKit for building portable CI/CD pipelines that can be run on any CI system or locally

name: Datadog Logs
description: Datadog logs is an additional feature of datadlog that provides log aggregation. We're in the early phase of trying out datadog logs as a replacement for splunk logs. The intent right now is for application logs only.

name: Datadog
description: Datadog is our primary tool for capture metrics, APM, monitoring, infrastructure, logs and more. We plan to expand our use of Datadog as we scale down our use of New Relic and Splunk

name: Datomic
description: Datomic is a unique database technology that we experimented with and deployed to production for attendee/rfid tracking purposes. We originally wanted to leverage the time based query capabilities of this unique database but have struggled with performance/scale as it comes to write throughput

name: Design Documents
description: Design documents is a fundamental part of SDLC where functional requirements and use cases get translated into a technical design for how we will build a solution. We expect that all teams are building design documents, reviewing them with architects, SRE and leads before writing code

name: Docker Desktop
description: We used docker desktop to run containers on our local machines up until they changed their licensing terms. At this point we recommend using an alternative like Rancher Desktop.

name: Docusaurus
description: A documentation platform that we experimented with for a few months. We abandoned it because we've been able to achieve the same features within CDF.

name: domo
description: We're currently using Domo as part of CEI but on a path to migrate toward other alternatives in 2024.

name: Dropwizard
description: Our primary microservices framework for Cvent

name: Elasticsearch
description: See AWS OpenSearch Service as we've deprecated our use of running Elasticsearch ourselves on EC2.

name: enzyme
description: Enzyme is widely at Cvent for React unit testing but it has been poorly maintained for several years and looks unlikely to ever support React past version 17

name: Gatling
description: Gatling is a load testing tool that we leverage to perform load testing of all our microservices

name: GitHub Actions
description: We're looking to migrate more CI/CD tooling over to GitHub Actions as we look to replace many uses of our internal Jenkins farm.

name: GitHub Copilot
description: We've started fully adopting Copilot in 2024 to help with developer efficiency.

name: GitHub Enterprise
description: We're looking to migrate towards GitHub in 2024/2025.

name: GraalVM
description: A new JVM runtime that can be used for fast startup time requirements, interop with multiple languages, cli, serverless and more

name: gradle
description: A build tool used by the java community with heavy use in the Android community. At Cvent we prefer Maven for a variety of reasons

name: Harness
description: We decided not to use Harness as we've pivoted towards other CI/CD solutions.

name: Helidon
description: We've chosen spring boot as go forward in 2024.

name: Hogan
description: Hogan is a combination of a git repo, cli tool and service for managing environment configuration information and credentials. We use this heavily throughout our CI/CD systems to manage configuration for all of the environments we support today

name: Jacoco
description: Jacoco is our primary code coverage tool for java projects

name: Java
description: Java is the language we use at Cvent to develop microservices and backend applications

name: JavaScript
description: JavaScript is used widely and is the only option for executing code in the browser (outside of webassembly). We're beginning our pivot to TypeScript and are recommending teams stop doing new development in JavaScript while slowly beginning to convert existing codebases over to TypeScript

name: JAWS Screen Reader
description: We leverage JAWS as a screen reader for testing accessibility.

name: Jenkins
description: Jenkins is our primary CI/CD tool today but are looking towards GitHub Actions for future.

name: Jest
description: Jest is the unit testing tool we use for typescript/javascript based projects at Cvent. We also leverage jest for integration tests when it makes sense

name: Junit
description: JUnit is the unit testing tool we use for java projects at Cvent

name: Karate
description: Karate is a test automation tool we're leveraging heavily for integration tests of all our REST/GraphQL APIs

name: Kotlin
description: Kotlin is used when we need native capabilities on Android that isn't supported by React Native

name: LaunchDarkly
description: We've aquired an enterprise wide license for Launch Darkly in 2024 and are hoping to have full rollout/migration complete by end of 2025 away from experiments.

name: Lerna
description: A tool for managing mono-repositories. Cvent has moved towards pnpm as the tool of choice for this since it replaces npm/yarn and lerna in one tool

name: Maven
description: The primary java build tool for managing dependencies and various build/deploy best practices at Cvent

name: Mermaid.js
description: A programmatic flowcharting and diagramming tool.

name: Micro Frontends
description: Micro frontends is a technique that brings some of the advantages of microservices to the frontend. We're experimenting with various methods that allow us to leverage this technique where appropriate. We've also looked into tools like bit.dev as a mechanism for managing this across the enterprise

name: Micronaut
description: We've chosen spring boot as go forward in 2024.

name: Microservices
description: Microservices is an architectural pattern where an application is broken up into discrete mini applications that can be built/deployed independentley and share nothing. This allows each component to be well understood, scaled, and modified independently from other teams

name: Middy
description: Middy is a middleware framework for AWS Lambda on Node.js (Javascript and Typescript applications). We use Middy for authentication and authorization middleware, Hogan Secrets integration, normalization, serialization and validations.

name: mob
description: mob is a command-line tool orchestrating mob programming discipline through git integration.

name: Mob Programming
description: Mob programming is an extension of pair programming applied to the whole agile team in a collective setting.

name: Mono Repositories
description: Mono repositories is a technique that allows a group of related components to all be developed in a single code repository. This often allows for easier maintenance of releases between related components and can provide significant boosts in productivity for teams. Cvent has several mono-repositories like (nucleus, carina, nx, mono-java and other mini mono repositories for various products)

name: Monoliths
description: Monoliths is an architectural pattern that normally involves a single application artifact and code repository. All development happens on the same artifact and the artifact gets deployed as a single unit. This is often a very efficient method for deliverying software when there's a limited number of teams with limited complexity. As the # of teams grow and the complexity increases it starts to hurt productivity. There are many other tradeoffs with this architectural style. At Cvent we recommend moving towards the microservice architectural pattern

name: MS SQL Server
description: MS SQL Server is one of the largest databases we use at Cvent today and is the primary relational database used behind large parts of app.cvent.com and related components. However, as we evolve we're putting a hold on continued expansion and use of this database as we prefer our relational databases move to AWS Aurora

name: New Relic
description: New Relic has primarily been an APM and browser tool that we've leveraged over the years to gain performance insights, errors and synthetic monitoring. As datadog has expanded it's capabilities we plan to migrate over time from New Relic to Datadog to unify under a single platform

name: NextJS
description: NextJS is the core web application framework that ships as part of CDF

name: Nexus
description: Nexus is our artifact repository as it acts like a cache/proxy to the rest of the internet

name: npm
description: NPM has been deprecated in favor of pnpm. There's a few primary reasons for this. 1) speed 2) mono repos

name: Nrwl/Nx
description: Nx (https://nx.dev/) is a build system designed to operate monorepos at scale. It adds computational caching and a host of other useful features to prevent the need to run every package in the monorepo every time.

name: Nucleus
description: A set of shared UI packages for building products

name: Objective C
description: Use Swift instead

name: Octopus
description: Our primary deployment orchestrator for staging and above

name: oktaws
description: oktaws is a cli tool that authenticates via okta federation. We're preferring this tool over cvent-aws-cli because it works with all AWS SDKs

name: Open API
description: Open API is how we define specifications for all our REST apis. It allows us to define a clear contract (request/response) for all our services to help with integration, test automation and clarity

name: Oracle
description: Oracle is another database leveraged heavily by Passkey, Conference and Business Transient product lines. However, as we continue to evolve we want to limit our investment in expanding the use of this database and leverage AWS Aurora

name: Phrase App
description: A localization framework we're leveraging to localize our products

name: pitest
description: A tool that helps you identify good tests from bad tests. This helps you avoid teams building tests that simply get code coverage without real test assertions

name: Playwright
description: Playwright is a test automation framework we're using for end to end testing of our web applications

name: pnpm
description: The build tool used by node projects and mono-repositories at Cvent.

name: Postman
description: We leverage postman as a tool for developing/testing APIs adhoc. Recent pricing changes & security concerns has pushed us away from using this going forward.

name: Prisma
description: Prisma is an interesting ORM that works well with graphql + typescript but has several short comings when it comes to how it handles transactions and joins. Prisma also uses a sidecar process to execute queries that severely hinders observability tools like Datadog. The side car process complicates connection pooling and IAM authentication and the sql generated is un friendly to RDS Proxy making it an unsuitable tool for serverless deployments. The approach we've taken to handle IAM results in memory leaks. For this reason weâ€™re putting this technology on Hold and looking for alternatives.

name: Python
description: Python is primarily used for scripting, data science and lambda functions where appropriate but the preference is to use TypeScript where possible

name: Quarkus
description: We've chosen spring boot as go forward in 2024.

name: RabbitMQ
description: We prefer that teams now use modern cloud native serverless messaging systems around our event driven architecture.

name: Rancher Desktop
description: We use rancher desktop to run containers on our local machines.

name: RAML
description: RAML is an api definition format for REST services. RAML is comparable to OpenAPI. We've consolidated our api definition language on Open API as it seems to have become the industry standard

name: React Native
description: Our primary UI framework for mobile

name: react-testing-library
description: The defacto standard tool for React unit testing

name: ReactJS
description: Our primary UI framework for the web

name: Release Bot
description: The release bot is a slack bot that helps us manage the queue of software changes that are going to production. This helps us coordinate who's next in line and avoids several changes happening at exactly the same time which often make it difficult to diagnose the exact cause of a failure

name: Renovate
description: An automation tool we're leveraging to help us maintain our software automatically

name: Request for comments (RFCs)
description: RFC is a process (and a wiki template) for putting together an idea or initiative to gather feedback from others.

name: Retrospectives
description: Cvent utilizes retrospectives to learn/improve. We have retrospectives on incidents, sprints, projects to help gain insights from the team

name: Ruby On Rails
description: A framework for building ruby web applications and services. This is currently leveraged by CrowdCompass to deliver the backend components for one of our mobile products

name: Ruby
description: A dynamic scripting language currently leveraged by CrowdCompass to deliver the backend components for one of our mobile products

name: Rust
description: We've began experimenting/learning Rust on tools like hogan cli, oktaws cli, hogan server to help with performance efficiency.

name: Scala
description: Used as a DSL for gatling load tests today but should generally stay close to primary languages of Java/TypeScript when possible

name: Serverless.com
description: We experimented with serverless.com early on as way to manage our adoption of serverless on AWS. While it worked well for prototyping, it failed when it comes to security/compliance and flexibility. Instead, we've deferred to leveraging AWS CDK

name: Single Page Applications
description: Single Page Applications (or SPA) is an architectural pattern where you load an applications UI once and then mutate state of the application on the fly without reloading the application. This is normally done by having the UI make API calls to the backend to change state or retrieve new data. At Cvent, many of our ReactJS applications follow this pattern. Gmail is a good example of an external SPA

name: Site Designer
description: A framework for exposing customizable web applications to end users based on Nucleus

name: Snowflake
description: Snowflake is a database used for business + product data combined as part of a data lake used by multiple business functions at Cvent.

name: Sonar
description: Sonar is a code quality tool we leverage to provide insights into the health of our code (quality, test code coverage, security vulnerabilities, bugs)

name: Spectral
description: Spectral is an open source API linter from stoplight.io. We use Spectral to lint OpenAPI and AsyncAPI specifications.

name: Splunk
description: Splunk continues to be used as part of security tooling at Cvent but we've migrated to Datadog for all application specific logging.

name: Spring Boot
description: A modern microservices framework we're beginning to use in 2024 as a replacement for Dropwizard

name: Swagger
description: Swagger is an api definition format for REST services. Swagger is comparable to RAML and is really the first version of OpenAPI. We've consolidated our api definition language on Open API

name: Swift
description: Swift is used when we need native capabilities on iOS that isn't supported by React Native

name: TailwindCSS
description: Tailwind CSS is a utility-based CSS framework, designed to rapidly develop modern websites. With Tailwind, developers can seamlessly build web applications without having to leave their HTML, making styling more efficient and streamlined. We are exploring the possibility of integrating Tailwind as our primary framework for application styling.

name: Terraform
description: Terraform is another infrastructure as code platform provided by hashicorp. We've decided to leverage AWS native services where possible since it really doesn't provide any value over what cloudformation/cdk provides. We also would rather not learn a new custom DSL

name: Trunk-based development
description: PRs against mainline with reliable automated test as part of CI

name: TypeScript
description: TypeScript is where we're putting a lot of our investment (React, CDK, NextJS). We're encouraging all developers to learn this language and are adopting this as our default language for many components within our technology stack

name: Vormetric
description: Vormetric is the platform we leverage for encryption of data at rest and field level encryption.

name: webdriver.io
description: webdriver.io is the test automation framework we're using for end to end tests. We prefer this framework because it supports selenium and chromium based workflows that allow for speed as well as comprehensive coverage across all the browsers that our products support

name: Whitesource
description: Whitesource is another tool we're leveraging to scan our dependencies, licenses, docker images and more.

name: yarn
description: Yarn has been deprecated in favor of pnpm. There's a few primary reasons for this. 1) speed 2) yarn2 breaking changes 3) mono repos
